name: Proteus
description: Proteus is a game about exploration and immersion in a dream-like island world where the soundtrack to your play is created by your surroundings. Played in first-person, the primary means of interaction is simply your presence in the world and how you observe it.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP SP3 Processor: 1.8GHz Memory: 3 GB RAM Graphics: Intel HD Graphics 3000 Hard Drive: 100 MB HD space
recommended_requirements: Processor: 2.2GHz Dual Core Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: 512 MB NVidia or ATI graphics card Hard Drive: 100 MB HD space

reviews.review_text: Proteus is a brilliant idea that only excels in its visual execution. It perfectly captures the kind of world once portrayed using just a few, two-toned pixels displayed from an Atari 800. A world that you, the viewer were forced to imagine rather than witness in high definition glory. The problem is; there is literally nothing to do within that world expect to wander its hills and valleys scaring off groups of animals while listening to the whimsical but unimpressive, procedurally-generated music. It is best described as a tech demo and it would make a fantastic screen saver akin to the classic Windows 3D maze. The one thing it is not however, is a game. 24 hours inside of Proteus would offer no more enjoyment or depth than simply watching its 2 minute long trailer video. And that is possibly the saddest thing I've ever written in review. While most indie games leave you wanting more for their own good reasons, Proteus leaves you to starve on an empty island for want of anything at all.

The game has nice music and looks pretty, but that's it.  For $12 you can walk around an island doing, well, nothing.  If you're deep enough to say  'I totally get this game, maaaan' , then sure, this game is probably right up your alley.  All the people who  get it maaan  have downvoted all the negative reviews. Such a great review system.
Like skyrim without anything

I'll be perfectly honest, when I first played this game I was at a point in my life when I was constantly feeling like ♥♥♥♥, soon enough later I was on anti-depressants, and now and then I get bad, but that's not the point.  I turned off my lights, put on my headphones and I was absorbed into an experience, calming vibrations, pleasant visuals, a walking simulator, yes. Proteus calmed me, it allowed me to colapse into a false world where I wandered and watch the seasons change, the wildlife pass and my essence rise above this small wonderful world below.  During some of the dark in my life, I occasionally find lights that help me move on and give me small comfort.

Another reviewer said that you can see all there is to see in this game in only ten minutes. Friend, you could not have been more wrong. My mind boggles to think how much work must have gone into this game, to make the experience so subtle that it takes some time to even realise that you are playing a game. But trust me: you are. The more you explore the Proteus world the more you realise that there's more to this world than pretty graphics and nice music.   The world responds to you. Not just to your simple actions, but to the emotions you're feeling in a particular part of the world because of what's going on, what's already happened and even what you already know. It's amazing that no matter what path I choose, the game always has something for me; a new experience that surprises me, even when I think I know what's coming.   If you don't like games without tick-box goals then maybe this one isn't for you. But if you're willing to put aside your search for objectives for a few minutes and just explore instead, you may find that you come across them anyway.

Get some quality mind-benders*. Combine with this chillaxer. Relax, and enjoy your trip.  Music is awesome. One of the best out there. Don't expect a game, expect a journey. Wait for a discount if in doubt.   (* — still enjoyable without them, tho)
I really like the art and sound design but everything else is wasted potential. A regular playthrough takes only around 30 minutes so beware.  2/5
This is more interactive artwork than a game. Seems simple at first but there's a ton of depth to discover, especially if you're interested in audio.
This game is very calming to play through

trippy.  drop some acid or smoke much pcp before playing, experience will be drop some acid or pcp because the experience will be drugs are best taken before polaying to enchance the drtugs pla y wiyth tdrugs to mkes game fun angeldust is best takjen to enchandsaa s
It is...special. And yeah, it is fun for a really short time. Is it worth the 10 bucks? Hell no, but you may think about getting it on sale.

Relaxing? Peaceful? No, just plain boring. While the game's description might sound interesting at first it did not meet my expectations with the music only slightly changing after passing certain points on the island.   Rather go outside or watch a screensaver with some calming music playing in the background, it'll be cheaper and also less mind numbingly boring than this.

As I stood among the totems of the dead gods on the mount, the world went silent save the blowing of the wind. Further up I walked and came across a lone tuning stone, an instrument for a ritual of the dead civilization. I sat there next to it and watched the sun set and the moon rise.   --------------------------  I walked among the trees of the summer, following the lines of the land. Bees appeared around me and gave me great swiftness to my destination. It brought me to the graveyard. Among the gravestones stood one that was blessed. Red flowers grew there, the last true grave of the people. The grave of my wife. None live that will bury me in the earth, my body shall rest upon the mount.  ---------------------------  I recommend this piece of art strongly.

I tried playing this game once before and I think I made it to fall(?) before dying of boredom. This time I made it the whole way through. Look I get it, this isn't an objective based game, it's not for everyone, bla bla bla. This game costs $10 regularly, and while a lot of people may argue it's worth that, (such as one reviewer with over 27 hours of gameplay) this is just not worth it to me. Honestly, you could enjoy Gone Home and Dear Esther and still find this game to be boring repetitive slog to get through. The soundtrack is honestly nothing special. Yes the music does change slightly based on where you are, what season it is, and what you are looking at, but it really never changes that much. This is not a game, it's a well-done art project. But it should be a free download. Just saying.
In autumn, at night time, find the circle of totems and stand in the miidle. Some freaky stuff happens. (reply if this happened to you)

A lot of people will quibble about whether Proteus is a proper game or not. Whatever you call it, it's fantastic, immersive, gorgeous and innovative, whether it's a 'game' or a 'interactive audio/visual experience.' Some people won't like this game. There are no goals or achievements or anything, no fail states, but that's not quite the same as there being 'nothing to do.'   It's simultaneously relaxing and transfixing, and unlike anything else. Pick it up while it's on sale for $2!

I keep coming back to this game for a truly relaxing, uplifting experience. I play it in the same way I'd play a favourite album, or watch a film I've seen twenty times - there's always something little you haven't noticed before.

Well, I got this game in a bundle, and at first I didn't think that I was gaoing to enjoy it, but I gave it a try. I'm glad I did. This little jewel places you in a beautiful island, and the only goal is to walk around and enjoy. It is wonderful how the environment makes the soundtrack to what you play, and how simple graphics can be so beatiful. A beautiful relaxing experience. It is definitely worth trying.
Catch this beauty while it's on sale, but it's worth it. The music and the atmosphere give it a nice soothing experience. this is pure art.

It is amazing it grabs you and drags you out of the world, it is really an experience worth going through, do i recommend it? yes of course i do :) amazing and outstanding way to make the player reach a variety of emotions with minimalistic graphics, and an amazins 'soundtrack' that is composed by our surroundings,   If you have not yet, than take part in this journey!
This isn't a game.  It's a dream.  ^_^
Chase pixelated 'things'

This is an odd exploration.... experience. I can't call it a game because you actually don't do anything except Experience the world around you. A very old-school, pixel/atari-type world. It's beautiful in its own way, calming, but not worth more than one or two play-throughs.  Get it when it's cheap, but get it.
whoa
Cool
So nice to walk around in this beautiful pixel wonderland! And that music, and the chirping birds...!

Proteus is the work of designer Ed Key and musician David Kanaga. The experimental game is an attempt to distill the adventure game down to its essence: exploration. Players open their pixelated eyelids to find themselves floating offshore from a mysterious island, which slowly reveals its secrets through subtle musical cues, psychedelically tinged 8bit-style graphics, and the changing of the virtual seasons.

It's a mix between a beautiful dream and an experimental ambient electronica piece. If you prefer explosions and platforming, skip Proteus, but if you want to explore a procedurally-generated world and discover its secrets, this is well worth it.  It has a magic feeling to it. The graphics look very low-fi in the stills, but when the game is in action, the illusion is so complete, it all works. While people who don't give Proteus a chance and play it through at least once say otherwise, the game DOES have a beginning and end, and completing it once unlocks a few extra options (including allowing the terrain generator to get a bit crazier).  The save system is very clever. If you want to save a particular random seed because you like the island you're on, hit F9 to save a postcard. This postcard is a screenshot of basically your perspective at that moment, but it's more than that. The game visually encodes data into the image, and the image acts as a save state: Not only will you return to that island, you'll return to that moment.  If you can handle going 30 minutes in a game without blowing something up or killing a terrorist, you should take a long moment to consider Proteus.

I had no idea what I was doing in this game at first, and just wandered around the world... soo... slowly.... I think I might have fallen asleep. I had to look up the 'point' of this game, and even then it was weird. I'm still not sure what the point of this game is, even after having 'beaten' it. Well, at least it's pretty, in a Minecraft pixel kind of way.
A calming adventure into a pretty little world. If you don't feel like relieving stress by massacring zombies or building in a sandbox, the music and visuals from this game may be more up your alley.

Very beautiful and calming. I like walking simulators and calm things so it's my perfect match. I did not know what this game was my brother bought it for me on Christmas and I liked it it was very enjoyable. Guys buy this game it's an awesome indie title
A divine experience that transcends your perceptions of life and ignites your senses. You are no longer sitting in your chair.

It's pretty good. I'm writing this review about 2 weeks after I beat it, so don't expect a huge complex review because i'm for sure not playing it again.  It's one of those games where you play it to completion and then never touch it again, similar to Journey. If you're into a rich experience with a few things to discover along the way, this is the game for you. There isn't too much gameplay and the island is very small and hard to explore because you walk so slow, but the progression of the story runs on secrets so once you faff about enough you can eventually find the place to go to the next area. I'm not going to spoil anything but the game certainly isn't as pretentious as the trailer looks, it's just a simply relaxing experience with no hidden 'message' along the way. that in itself may seem like an odd thing to say in a review, but it's one of the main things that almost stopped me from buying the game. I didn't quite like the ending, and although it was powerful it lasted way too long. The main part- the music, wasn't too special. It was relaxing but after a while it all started to sound too samey. It's possible that was the point though, as the whole island seems dreamlike at points and really chills you out.  Overall, while this game is extremely relaxing with a great atmosphere, it probably isn't for everyone. While I did find a few secrets along the way I do not believe there is any replay value or incentive to even start up the game again after completing it. You also walk almost as slow as 'Dear Esther' so don't expect to be cruising around the island looking at things. The whole game takes time. I bought Journey for 15 dollars, beat it in an hour and didn't regret it at all due to the artistic quality and depth of the game. I bought this game for 10 and beat it in an hour as well, and feel the same way. Buying this game is like buying a ticket to an art gallery, just sit back and look at the paintings. If you're not into that, I would keep on walking as this game won't change your mind.
This game is perfect together with a joint and some vodka. Bring painkillers and toiletpaper for best experience. 10 out of 10, must have.

THIS GAME IS THE BEST    GAMEPLAY   30/5    STORY   SO GOOD DOESN'T EVEN NEED ONE    ACTION   =   SHREK      RECOMMENDED     As you can obviously see this is a game of love, drama, betrayal, and action for the sacrifice to protect the things you care about most.      BUTTERFLIES

The way in which the world paints itself before you is captivating. Each player will explore their own generated Elysium, and it is the trait of curiosity that will lead the most observant through an unravelling maze. Looks pretty too.
Beautiful, peaceful, reassuring and lets you have boring arguments about what games are.

This game is great. I bought it off of impulse when it was only $2.50, and I'm VERY glad I did.  Unlike most modern day games, there is no other characters, no monsters, no leveling, no upgrades. The entire game is fully exploration-based. You have to find some stone circles, and they shift you from season to season, until you finish the game.   Even though this game is a pixel-type game, the graphics and dynamics are amazing. The landscapes are everchanging, and beautiful. Clouds move in over the flatlands at night, the sun rises and sets, as does the moon. Heck, there are even shooting stars! The most unique element to this game is the music. Nobody will ever listen to the same music, ever. It all depends where you go. If you go near trees, you'll hear some additions to the music. If you go to a flower field, then you'll hear the music of the flowers. When you're walking through the landscape, it will all just blend together into a great, and truely unique musical score. If you are hesitant about getting this amazing game, don't be. You'll be very glad you did.

(7/10) Interesting little interactive design. Its not exactly a game on its own but it is an interesting place to explore for a while and expirament with. Not particularly deep or long but it doesn't really need to be to share its mood and tone with you.

Amazing! This game has an atmosphere like no other. It is very surreal. The music playing all the way through, constantly changing is excellent and and can be influenced by things in the world like the little creatures, or the owl. The game gets to its best during winter, the music is beautiful but sad during this part of the game, echoing what I can only presume is, well I can't tell you! You need to experience this. During the end of winter, I got goose bumps, but I will not spoil it. One of the most beautiful peices of art I have ever experienced. If you do drugs this may be an opportune use for them, it will get even more surreal.
WOW i mean WOW  very relaxing game   deffinatly get this if you just need to chill out for a bit a clear your thoughts

I launched the game and was met with a barrage of loud noise. After turning the master volume down to a reasonable 10% through the clunky options menu (where audio is in the 'others' section), I went to actually play the game. Without a play button I had to smash around the screen to get it to play. Interesting choice but whatever. Then my game cut to a black screen, locked up, and refused to close. I had to do some back-alley nasty stuff to get the game to close, as it took screen priority on Win8's desktop and refused to let anything else overlap it.  Waste of time, broken, poor interface. Would not recommend.
This is a really beautiful and peaceful experience. I can't say that I'd want to spend hours upon hours exploring it but I really enjoyed the little amount of time that I spent with it!
The only game I've ever played that has actually given me chills when it starts snowing.

good atmosphere. a pretty fun little game if you want a short and pleasant game about wandering around on a pretty and mysterious island for half an hour. i'm glad i didn't pay full price, though, since it's so short and simple, but i'm glad i played it

Can't talk smack about this game because it's an indie and the creators would just say 'it's a game for intellectuals and we were trying to have stylized graphics'  Kinda wish Indie devs would grow a mothertrucking backbone

Some time ago I had this dream. I stood on top of a mountain - The sun was mild and the wind passed through my ears. Trees and flowers dismantled in a shower of petals and flowers, and I was only uneble to hear the world singing because of the wind, singing louder. Where was anxious or angry, I sought to close my eyes and go back to that place of my dreams, where only the wind could speak to me.  Well... This game took me there.
what I 've done with my life?

Proteus is an exceptional and definitive 'notgame' that is easier to explain by what it isn't. It isn't about passive story telling. It isn't about objectives or achievements. It isn't about simulating realistic environments. It isn't about efficiency or mastery. Most importantly, it isn't about you, which itself is marvelous for a video game. Proteus doesn't want to thank you for saving it. Instead it wants to offer a glimpse of what was, is, and always will be, with or without your interaction.  So many games are psychological exercises in transitioning chaos into order, weakness into strength, beginner into expert, boring grass into busy city, and at the crux is you as the agent of transition. I am not immune to dopamine's effect when completing these types of games, and I definitely enjoy them. Yet when I think back at what these addictive games have taught me about myself it's that I need to justify my free time with feelings of accomplishment.  Proteus is the antithesis of typical addictive games; there is no feeling of loss and thus no reason to save. It deconstructs the spatial awareness of Doom and the floral and faunal mystery of Super Mario 64. It is about discovery and wonder. It is about recognizing aliens. It is about finding frequencies. It is about turning off sight to focus on sound, and vice versa. It's also a challenge to status-quo game designers to stop being lazy and comfortable. Have we really come that far from Doom and Super Mario 64? Is it benefiting anyone creatively by continuing those types of games ad-nauseum? And the much more interesting question that was raised by Paolo Pedercini: can the industrial rationalization of goal-oriented video game design be replaced by chaotic, paradoxical, and human design within the influence of our capitalist society?  Radiohead and Universal Everything recently published a free app with a very similar design to Proteus called PolyFauna. On their website, Dead Air Space, they clearly and concisely list the app's mechanics, not its plot or objectives - just as music, film, portraits, or sculptures would not have those things. So what if Proteus is considered art? It is beautiful, inspiring, or meaningless depending on your interpretation, not the designers'. You don't need it to have endless appeal like a FPS or RPG. But just like a piece of art, you might feel inclined to hang on to it, occasionally appreciating it by yourself or with others. Even if playing around in Proteus' pixelated ecosystem for only an hour causes you to feel differently about how you spend your free time, then it will have been worth a purchase.

Very relaxing and chill 'game'. The content comes from exploring an island that is a bit different every time you visit.  A lot of time has to pass before you will see something you havent' seen before, so don't get discouraged when you feel like you've seen the same things every time you play.
It's simply a pleasant experience

I went into this blind, but was pretty let down. Expected more to do and see. Think the concept is good but it just needs more of everything. Wouldn't pay $10, but if theres a good sale it might be worth a $2 run through.

Boo to those people who didn't recommend.   This game is a beautiful, peaceful game about exploration that can suck you in for an hour or two. There is no interaction, just walking around the gorgeous landscapes and listening to the music and herding frogs.  A wonderfully relaxing game for any stress needing to be relieved.
Very very strange. Not a game, but more of an experiance. Wouldn't reccomend it to a normal gamer.

Video games teach us to follow linear pathways to achieve a clear objective and reach a single, desirable end, a clear 'game over' where we know we've succeeded or failed. Proteus could not deviate from that system farther. The first time I opened the game (which was just now), I found myself tearing up over... well, it's beauty, it's adventure, it's hard to describe. It's Proteus. (now admittedly I'm a huge wimp, but the experience was really emotionally moving, and not at all something I expected from a video game :P) It felt like five minutes of gametime; my Steam says I've logged five times that much. If any game is truly magical, it's Proteus.  Most games are easily beatable with a lot of grinding and the help of a google search, a wiki, or a friend, but the thing about Proteus is you don't 'beat' it. You just play it. That's somewhat of a radical thing in video games, I think, and it makes playing Proteus a real stress-relieving experience. There's nothing to tell you what's going to happen, or even how you go about making it happen - that's what playing the game is for! You explore, you learn, you discover. It's a game that doesn't bend itself to the will of a dedicated, competitive player, it's a game that takes you along for an adventure. The music has the quality of pre-composed pieces but is formed naturally as you explore the environment, which changes with what seems to be a mind of its own. Swim to that island. Bump into that rock. Follow that blue hopping thing. Who knows where you'll end up? I don't. My mom don't. The wiki don't. At least I sure hope it don't... This game is whatever you want it to be, so I encourage any players not to start with asking what they can find or how to find it, but just to hop into the game and enter their own little dreamscape where anything and everything can happen. :3  On the practical side the game is very friendly with the options. You can play it fullscreen or in a window and you can adjust your field-of-view and mouse sensitivity very easily and even do it ingame if you please. The creators have pulled out all the stops to make sure this game is a convenient and comfortable experience as well as a beautiful one. I reckon I'd pay the full ten bucks for it, but if you can, get it on sale; whenever you can get your hands on it, Proteus will be waiting for you. :P  The game's not for everyone, but if you enjoy video games as an art form, if you're looking for a truly unique adventure that's both dynamic and peaceful at the same time, and heck, if you just flippin want to, give Proteus a try. This is a world I wouldn't mind going to when I die.
I chased a bunny until it jumped into the ocean.

Somebody told me that 'Proteus' was an experience like 'Journey' (PS3 game). And his opinion was a ♥♥♥♥, like this 'game'. This is not an experience, it's a nonsense boring lonely walk trough a ridiculous world. 'Journey' really is an experience.

Literally all you do in this game is walk around a world and look at it. This might be a cool concept if the game didn't look like it was made on a calculator. Now I'm NEVER someone to say a game is bad just because of the graphics, but when a game's primary focus is its visuals, exploration, and all that, it NEEDS to be at least remotely pleasing to the eye, which this game is not. Don't let the trailer fool you like it did for me. This is not some quirky game where the worlds are full of fun mysteries and wonders to unravel. You walk around a boring world that you can't do anything in and where nothing is interesting. You're basically spending $10 to have your eyes ♥♥♥♥♥ and your sense of boredom sent to a new peak.
I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone.
This is not a game. This is just a simple terrain made in Unity that the developer decided to release instead of finishing his game.
I don't know why but this game is terrifying for me.
10/10 Best song I ever played

Proteus is a joy to experience. Contrary to some folk, I always find new things to do each time I take a wander - it is up to you what you do and where you go. Sometimes I just like to watch a sunset, stare at the sun or stars, or watch the clouds roll by in the lowlands. Other times, I go chasing chickens and see where I can get them to. When it is dark, I go and try to find owls. In all honesty, I find Proteus to be an intense experience (in a good way) in which I have to turn down the lights, put the headphones on and minimize all other distractions. Go explore! There is plenty to do.

I'm not sure this is really how I want to spend my time.  The game world is definitely curious. Granted, I wish that there were more lighting effects. I really want to see the trees cast shadows, and the sky to have a gradient to it. Maybe something like global illumination too, maybe. The absence of any sort of lighting effects makes the world feel off, like it's a strange land where everything is alien.

Pre-alpha demo of a project that never materialized, shoveled into Steam with a €10 price tag.  They call it 'Proteus'.  Instead of playing this pixelated mess, I can watch the seasons change in photorealistic graphics by looking out of my window.
For a game of just some pixels it is absoloutely beautiful! But not really with a $10 tag, wait for a sale to come on :)
For a game of just some pixels it is absoloutely beautiful! But not really with a $10 tag, wait for a sale to come on :)
The most pleasurable, astonishing and breathtaking evasion from reality that i have ever experienced.
If you want a copy of the game for $7.50 inbox me. I have TWO coppies.

wow.... WTF is this? lets put it this way, this game was so boring, i saw a VIRUAL FROG, and started flipping ♥♥♥♥, I was so excited, followed it for a while, then realized, 'wow, im chasing a frog....'
i hate my life so much but this game is my life so therefore i hate this game so much 10/10 indie
i did it. i played it for more than 5 minutes.. wow...  1/10   (however, thanks for gifting it to me, reddit!)

Look now I'm no fully sane person myself. But let me level with you for a second. I myself have never ingested drugs before or I do not wish too.....BUT! If you are someone whose down for that stuff then, and only let will you most likely understand this game for it's true beauty. <3 If you're a normal person it's not that good eh.? Sorry makers of this game. 2/10 - soundtrack is aight (still probably more of a high person's forte).

This game is freakin' beautiful, 'nuff said. If you're feeling ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off from playing some other game and need a break, this game is perfect for relaxing. Just put on some headphones, and take it in. The atmosphere is just perfect. I was a bit disappointed that it was so small, but I still think it's one game I'll actually go back to at least occasionally. Sequel, please.
DUDE SO COOL BREH DEM PIXELS BREH Way too much money for a game that can be completed in less than ten minutes which no exploration. Its purely an expeirence and its what you make of it.
0/10 try harder
life changing experience , much trippy, many color

It's already been said, but this game really isn't all it's cracked up to be. I've played artsy games before and I usually enjoy them; but this isn't even that. The 'art' in it isn't nice, at all... I wouldn't mind walking around the island if it was actually nice to look at. I'm fine with pixel art (Minecraft is gorgeous at times after all) but this just seems to have no effort put into it.  Also, not sure if this was a problem just with my game, but I wasn't even able to access the 'options' and 'help' menu, and as such I hated how slow and clunky the movement felt. I was having to move my mouse far too much just to turn around, and I'm not sure what you're supposed to be playing as, but the eerie floating through space thing isn't fun.  This game could do with some interaction in it, honestly. No combat is fine, and definitely could work, but having things just constantly run from you gets boring fast. And the random statues and houses dotted around for seemingly no reason just add to the overall feeling of pointlessness.

Not a game, and not much to it. There are no mechanics to speak of. You just walk and look at the roughly 6 things there are to see, change a season and see the same 6 things in a slightly different color scheme, then you're done. There is no plot, and the most interesting thing about it is that ambiant music stems from what's around you (And that's been done much better elsewhere). It's essentially a zen program; An awfully expensive one. Watch a Let's Play on YouTube if that interests you at all, you'll see all there is in short order.

Not a game, and not much to it. There are no mechanics to speak of. You just walk and look at the roughly 6 things there are to see, change a season and see the same 6 things in a slightly different color scheme, then you're done. There is no plot, and the most interesting thing about it is that ambiant music stems from what's around you (And that's been done much better elsewhere). It's essentially a zen program; An awfully expensive one. Watch a Let's Play on YouTube if that interests you at all, you'll see all there is in short order.

There's no gameplay or narrative. There's nothing to interact with and no beautiful vistas to see. It lacks the humour and discovery of The Stanley Parable and isn't as beautiful or striking as Dear Esther.   I don't understand why anyone would like this game. You wander around a not particlarly pretty island. That's the entire game, apparantly.

There is no plot, and the most interesting thing about it is that ambiant music stems from what's around you (And that's been done much better elsewhere). It's essentially a zen program; An awfully expensive one. Watch a Let's Play on YouTube if that interests you at all, you'll see all there is in short order.

Do not get this game. I am so happy I didnt pay money for this. It's like a wierd interactive art piece. I felt like I was back in a place well before Doom, with no gun, and no point. Seriously, the space bar is 'Sit'. I feel like this could be cool if it was coded for one of those competitions where you have to keep it under 64k.

There's no gameplay or narrative. There's nothing to interact with and no beautiful vistas to see. It lacks the humour and discovery of The Stanley Parable and isn't as beautiful or striking as Dear Esther.   I don't understand why anyone would like this game. You wander around a not particlarly pretty island. That's the entire game, apparantly.
Boring. Want to walk around a pixelated island and have absolutely nothing happen? Sure, buy this game! Like decent games? Stay away.

Have you ever played a game where the mechanics were so rich you felt like you could refine the entire thing into one concept and it would still be great? That feeling may work for many games but most of the time you won’t find out one way or the other. Most designers and gamers alike understand that games are an amalgamation of many ideas rather than a thoroughly impressive one-trick pony. This understanding seems to have evaded the creators of Proteus, or maybe they thought their game was exempt. Proteus is a one-concept tech demo that might’ve been neat if it was part of something bigger but what’s there isn’t enough to keep your interest or justify the seemingly inoffensive price.  The concept of Proteus is relatively brief. You control a first-person character that starts off in the ocean with an island in sight on the horizon. Once you get to the island, your only source of interaction is what you walk next to. The game reacts to your presence by playing different music depending on your location and occasionally there is a sprite animal or insect that runs away from you. That is the entire game. There is “progression” and an “endpoint,” but not in the way you might hope for. Endings are usually synonymous with finales or closing thoughts. Proteus’ ends a lot like a High School final project. They probably could’ve kept prolonging it for a better grade but the class already lost interest and the teacher gave a glance that implied what they had was good enough.  That’s not to say that “good enough,” is actually any good. Proteus’ quality hinges on the music and visuals, neither of which is very impressive. The artwork may be appealing in screenshots, but the environment remains completely static during gameplay. There are occasional lighting effects which add a bit of variety but nothing to make up for the overall stiffness of the game. As a result, the world feels very lifeless and the lack of interaction from the player doesn’t help.   The music doesn’t add much personality either. Proteus’ concept of “different music plays depending where you are” certainly works but the sounds you’re hearing sound like placeholders rather than actual music. Most of the tracks sound like someone pressing buttons to see if the instrument is working rather than playing actual music. This blunder contributes to the feeling that Proteus is an undeveloped tech demo, not an actual game.  If you somehow “finish” Proteus, you won’t be getting much more from the experience than the person who loads it up for five minutes and closes it out of disinterest. This game may be the latest discussion in the “are games art” debate but I’d argue that Proteus offers absolutely nothing to the player. There is no interaction to speak of, the music is amateurish, the visuals are mediocre and the experience is pointless. There is no message or mood established in Proteus, it’s the definition of wasting time. Proteus may serve as inspiration for a mechanic that’s a part of a bigger game, but on its own there’s nothing worth playing.
It's a waking game, it's not art it's just ♥♥♥♥ing stupid.
Walkabout and do nothing. Looks pretty though. But only playable if high or you only have it installed and no interenet access. Overall Rating: 1/10

Can't choose the words to describe this experience... All you should know - follow your own marks and you'll be happy... This is about changes. What's changes? Everything you see around! Try out this game!
I'd probably enjoy it on acid. Too bad drugs are illegal. Not recommended.
I play this when I'm really ratzn it from life  Ya feel me?

I played this for 15 minutes before getting bored. I took a leap of faith from people that told me 'you have to just experience it!!!' yeah it was interesting for about 5 minutes, then I spent 10 minutes wandering around before scouring it from my hard drive forever.
fun for 2.7 hours
Like Skyrim with musical bunnies.

It´s beautiful... but 10 bucks? Nope! Nope! Nope! This is essential Minecraft, without the interaction. Imagine Minecraft where you can´t affect the world. That is Proteus.  You are a floating camera in a random created world. You have no goal. You can only experience sounds and visions. But there is nothing to discover, nothing to experience. It tries to pass random sounds and sights of as depth... but a random block (a frog) that emits random sounds ain´t that different from a random pack of blocks (birds?) that emits different random sounds.  I feel that even 2 dollars were to much for this experience. For 10 bucks you can take a bus trip to a part of town you´ve never been. That experience would be more meaningful than 7minutes of this pretentious waste of time.
nothing really happens
This game is beautiful. Go into it with an open mind though, because this is definitely not a game for everyone --- especially not if they expect a game in the traditional sense.
Almost caught the Dragon!

a nice little game thats peacfu to explore but sometimes plays high pich music that hurts my head and sounds like i should be in space. but deffinitly a must buy if you like pixalated walking simulators.

Interesting for max 10mins. You can have 70% of the game experience by watching the video on the store page... Not worth buying. Except you are a huge teletuby fan or you have a toddler you want to spoil with videogames, then buy it.
This games pretty ♥♥♥♥, Got it free in a bundle.  You just walk around a forest. That's it
Atmospheric, immersive game, if you can call it that.  Worth a try.

This is a great game. Especially if you can appreciate it. Now there are some people in the world who will complain. 'THIS GAME SUCKS! WHERE ARE ALL THE GUNS?!' or 'THESE GRAPHICS ARE NOTHING COMPARED TO MY CALL OF DUTY!' Well, these graphics might be 'crap' but to me, that simplicity just adds to the beauty of it. This game is the only game that's brought me to tears and made me feel at peace.
Escape reality for a while.

So the other day I got high as hell and played this game. I was walking around and ♥♥♥♥ until I got to part where the bees circle around you and make you go fast. I had such a connection with them, I felt that they were my children and I had to protect them from the evils of the world. Everytime they left me I felt a sadness inside myself, but I accepted that things in life come and go and sometimes you just have to accept it and move on. Oh yeah and the jumping frogs made me giggle. This is more of an experiance than an actual game, but that doesn't make it any less fun, the graphics are low res but I like that because of the pretty colors and sound.  7.5/10 play it high for the best time.

Kind of like a 320x200 video game rendering of 'Koyaanisqatsi.' Not just because its primary appeal is its visuals, but also because of its pretty neat, procedurally generated, Phillip Glass-esque score. The primary mechanic is exploration and the combination of the audio and visuals make it play more like a sort of extended tone poem than a 'game,' but there are interactive elements and new things to see and discover on different playthroughs.   Not sure if there's enough there to warrant many play throughs, but it is incredibly....relaxing. Its cumulative effect is a bit like popping a couple valium and listening to one of those self-hypnosis relaxation tapes (which wouldn't be a compliment if referring to most games, but in Proteus' case it is). In fact, it's so relaxing that I kind of find the demand to control it to be a bit of an impediment at times. Someone needs to make an 'auto-wander' mod for it so I could turn it on and veg out when I'm stressed or just fall asleep to it.
A very beautiful and relaxing piece of art. Don't expect a game.
As a game its...lacking to be polite. But it would make a nice screen saver.
$9.99 worth of acid trips  tl;dr it's pree good lol
realtime wildlife harrassment simulator  A++ would recommend

If you like tripping balls and pixely graphics, this game is pretty cool. You wal around in pretty nature settings, and every once in awhile something bizzare happens. It's a 'day at the magical pixel park' simulator 2k13
Visit Proteus. Touch it. Close your eyes. Listen. The clouds roll on, unmoved.
Extremely boring, nothing at all happens, walking speed is extremely slow. Avoid at all costs
Recommended for anyone looking to chill out with something a little different.
Luckily I didn't spend much one this game. But my 5 year old neice enjoyed this game. I guess I got some value out of it.

Gorgeous pixel-art, amazing generative/interactive soundtrack created by the various elements of the enviroment, and your relationship/intereactions with them.  What is it? A peaceful meditation, a beautiful little journey, and something that had me smiling the entire trip through the 4 seasons on the island.  Love it.
It's better than real life
This game never ceases to amaze me with it's spontinaity and beauty. Worth it.

2015 edition, Might make you smile and cry. Depends how much you read into it I guess.   Had a review for this title once, felt it was too childish as it was, but it came from the feeling the game gave me. Now I'm writing a short one again as I finish the game a second time. I did not live to see the aurora this time...  It's a brief walk on a small island. Four different seasons to see and listen. Until the end. That's it. For some it's just that and bit boring. For me. It's like watching the Snowman cartoon as a child for the first time during christmas time. It's like stepping into the forest of Mononoke Hime for a brief moment or strolling in the woods of Mushishi. The visuals, music and sound in complete control of my mood. It's pretty hard to rate or explain stuff like that. Obviously things like this won't work always like charm, but it did twice for me.  I just wish someone could take stuff like this and put it into a longer and more complete package.

Personally I would not recommend this game as it plays more like an interactive screensaver than an actual game. you might play it for 30 mins or even an hpur but you will always feel you wasted your time,this is a blatant case of style over substance

Proteus is my personal chilling simulator. You walk around the island, find a nice spot, and just sit down and chill for a bit. It's not the most exciting game, but it succeeds in creating places and sounds that are soothing, and sometimes slightly creepy.  It's more of an experience than a game. I really like it, though.
I recommend you just play minecraft with Brian Eno's Thursday Afternoon on constant repeat. Proteus is a bit ♥♥♥♥.

Thought I would try one of these 'artsy/poetic' games. Thought it would be interesting, but it was pretty boring. The main screen left me a little confused on how to even start playing. Thought I had to hit the title screen but it was apparentlly the image (you can interact with pretty much everything on the main screen.) I get it is supposed to be some walk and enjoy the scenery game, but the art style just didn't do it for me. Just blocky trees and mountains and I guess things supposed be animals like baby chicks. The music in the beginning sounded like some weird alien sci-fi-esque tune, Later on it sounded okay. Either way, felt the music choice didn't really fit the walking around. The only slightly amusing thing I guess was the little bouncing characters(which when I followed seemed to lead me to the water?) but that's about it. There's is no set place to go, just walk around and explore the one island, where everything looks very similar but in maybe two different colours. If you like an interactive screensaver or want something soothing before you go to sleep, check it out.
It was a beautiful Zen game that made me feel relaxed and happy, and the ending had me sitting in my seat with mouth agape in total awe! I definitely recommend this game!

Has all the gameplay of Dear Esther, without any of the plot or detailed graphics.  Truthfully, it's more art project than game and it is relaxing in its own way. You need to be in the mood for something like this, and given the short playtime (my first was < 40 minutes) you may or may not get a lot ouf of it.  The 'relaxing' and 'walking simulator' tags say it all. If you like pixel graphics on top of it, this will be your cup of tea. It's nearly mine, but there's just not enough here for me to enjoy.
em.....i don't get this is it litaraley a walkeing sim i don't know what to do HELP by the way i love the art stile is awsame 10000000000000000/10
You just wander around a colorful island. That's it.

This is one of those games were you just need to walk and listen to your surroundings. Everything in this game makes a sound one way or another and can create beautiful atmosphere. Use this game when your feeling mad or just got ticked off and want to sit back and relax!
It's not really a game as much as it is a thing.
A very beautiful and relaxing piece of art. Don't expect a game.

For anyone interested in an immersive experience, for anyone who intends to make an immersive game- Play this.  Too often in games we get caught up in the particular details that we shut ourselves off from the experience of the game world. Rediscover that feeling.

Proteus uses the first-person perspective and the ability to walk around as a canvas on which to paint images and music, developing by the end into a coherent whole. If you go in demanding to be impressed and entertained, you will miss the point. It's a subtle experience.
Actually pretty nice.

Proteus is probably the weirdest games I've ever played. It has no storyline, no objective, nothing telling you what to do. Its just a 3D 8 bit world were you just walk around and explore. Although personally I do think the price is extremely step at £6.99 for a game where you walk around and do virtually nothing, its pretty nice and relaxing.

I have played this game for 15 minutes and I am already bored. There is nothing to do other than follow a couple animals and look at nature that isn't even that spectacular. A waste of time and money. The only good thing about the game is the music. 1/10
I'm just happy that this came free in a Humble Bundle. What a waste of time, not even worth the hard drive space.

I love proteus. I played it about a year ago for the first time and it didn't really click with me. The island was interesting, but I quickly came around to 'that's it?' and promptly stopped playing it, thoroughly bemused by the review scores I had seen from major magazines. I reinstalled it a few days ago and, not really expecting anything, I just started going around my little randomly generated island. I made friends with the animals, found out that the rocks made cool noises and just explored. I had no idea what was going on, but because I kept trying new things out at different times of day, interesting and often beautiful and mysterious things kept happening. And I ultimately came upon the ending in a profoundly affecting way because I didn't see it coming at all, I was just in a relaxed trance, taking things as they came.  Exploring new islands is wonderfully relaxing. Familiar and yet unknown. It has the effect of being in nature for a few hours... really remarkable for something you do on your computer and a great contrast to shooting people in the head.
This game is piece of art. It is surprisingly fun and sedative to just walk on a beautiful, randomly generated island and watch seasons pass. And the ending....I love this game.
Pretty boring and pointless.

I got this in a humble bundle, and so i decided to try it, and i am like wtf is this. the only positive thing to this is all the wird landscape and wierd animals. my favourite part is how your eyes sloly close as you hold escape, but thats about it. Its a good game if you like constantly looking at brightly iluminated landscape artwork that moves, but otherwise don't buy it.
Guys this game is awesome once you understand it

Has all the gameplay of Dear Esther, without any of the plot or detailed graphics.  Truthfully, it's more art project than game and it is relaxing in its own way. You need to be in the mood for something like this, and given the short playtime (my first was < 40 minutes) you may or may not get a lot ouf of it.  The 'relaxing' and 'walking simulator' tags say it all. If you like pixel graphics on top of it, this will be your cup of tea. It's nearly mine, but there's just not enough here for me to enjoy.
It doesn't matter to me whether Proteus is a game or not - I keep returning to it just to listen, relax and explore. It's beautiful.

Amazing. Absolutely fantastic. It's relaxing, it's beautiful, and it made me smile with glee on more than one occasion. The music is wonderfully done, and the way every single thing in the area changes it makes it amazing and so it never gets boring. There are small creatures to interact with, that are cute and have sound that meshes so perfectly with the music from your surroundings, and it's nice to have something that doesn't involve killing and that has no dark storyline. Overall just a fantastic game.
Love the music, but I got bored really quickly.
Definitely worth it when it's on sale. Nothing has had a more relaxing effect than this game.
I got it when it was on sale for like 2 dollars. Short game, great music. It feels like my brain is being probed by aliens from Communion.
It is simply beatiful

For anyone interested in an immersive experience, for anyone who intends to make an immersive game- Play this.  Too often in games we get caught up in the particular details that we shut ourselves off from the experience of the game world. Rediscover that feeling.
Beautiful, sleepy little gem of a non-game game. If you enjoyed Dear Esther then you'll enjoy the silent story behind Proteus.
Buy this game if you want to hang out in a rad-looking lo-fi world for a while

Stunning. Just finished and I just kept repeating 'wow' over and over. No this isn't a game for everyone. Only 30 minutes long. The entire world is pixelated. There is no dialouge. You can basically explore through each pixelated season. Just the way the graphics were done mixed with the music really amazed me. I think it's beautiful.
Great music 'game'. The whole playthrough was pure art.
If I wanted to walk around looking at things wouldn't I go outside instead?
This game is my happy place.

This game is gorgeous, only being based around just exploration. No hunger bars or health bars, just being calm. I personally chill wif a cup of tea and play it ^-^ it is beautiful and it's just decorated with amazing music, best playedd with headphones. I will always love this game, it shall never be boring, plus cheaper than it should be.
Interesting, and not what I would classicly term a game, but captivating all the same. Worth at least one playthrough, if only to see what can be done with a limited pallette and evocative sound.

Interactive screensaver i read from a forum post for this and it sums it up quite nicelly. I thought id give it a try, i think this had potential but you just walk around a small island doing the same thing.

Alright, if you thought Gone Home 'wasn't a game' because it didn't involve shooting dudes in the face well you really won't like this one. Proteus puts you on a procedurally-generated island, with graphics that will show off the horsepower of your new 386. It's a vacation to a magic land of pixelated trees and wildlife, where fireflies dance in the woods at night and a circle of mysterious stones can take you to the next season - spring, summer, fall and winter all have different characters. There's an ending of sorts, but the entire game is calm, slow, plotless, but graphically stunning in its low-resolution way. Certain vistas made me gasp or smile when I moved through them. The music is also procedural, setting ambient electronic mood that matches perfectly with the visuals. I like to just run it in the background to play the music.  Proteus is digital antidepressant and well worth experiencing from time to time when you need to destress.  NOTE: On Mac OS X, it took over a minute of black screen at the beginning before it came up - just be advised to wait without any kind of feedback before the title screen. I had thought it had crashed several times before I waited.
I don't know if I played the game, or the game played me, but I do know it was very enjoyable!

I initially thought Proteus would be like Dear Esther (which I didn't like at all) and I got it from a humble bundle. Well it's not.  Proteus is a piece of art!  It entertained me 43 minutes straight and it's something I'd show other people.   The soundscapes were very pleasant, as were the animations and colour palettes. Not a fan of the huge pixels, I don't thiknk they're cute, I think they're hideous, but the complete picture is still aesthethically pleasing.

This game reminds me of a time in my teens, going to the fair and paying money to peek in a majestic aquarium and see a mermaid. I don't know what I actually thought I'd see, probably nothing amazing, but it ended up being a really ugly old fat man in a one piece bathing suit and an XXL long sleeve green tshirt around 'her' legs, sitting at the bottom of a disguised dunk tank. I paid one dollar and fifty cents to see that man and this game disappointed me more.   Its exactly what you'd expect, except with less going on. It's peaceful, but if that's what you're into, hiking in real life is free at a lot of places and the rabbits are more than 4 pixels. It was the anticipation that made me hate it, if I just stumbled across this for free, coded into a web page, I'd probably play for five minutes and then stop and be like, 'Hey, that was sort of cool.'  You can press Q, and it auto-walks forward, and you just look around with the mouse with really not much other than trees to see, aside from a few graves, and the changing time of day. I think a lot of people are arguing that this is art, or this game is just trying to be different and show that you don't need goals or objectives, but from my perspective, many of those people are just fighting the norm, playing the devil's advocate. I can't see someone spending more than 20 minutes max on this game.  Overall: 2/10 for being pretty.
Bucolic, as if Wordsworth had access to C++
Such a beautiful experience. It has more than it seems at first. A wonderful journey!
It used to burn when I tweet, but since playing Proteus, it no longer does.

This game is perfect if your just ready to relax and listen to some cool dynamic music.  If you are expeecting a game with puzzles and action and shooting and stuff, then this game is not for you.  Its music that changes with where you are and what your doing makes it perfect.   9/10

In the my first hour, Proteus has reminded me strongly of the few precious times I have spent out of the city, using a single island, four seasons, and evocative (and dynamic) music.  The music and the voxel-ly art style are striking. Proteus plants you along the shore of an island; all you have to do is explore it. Each time you get a new procedurally-generated island that is varied and wonderful and full of new landmarks. Walk and sit and take postcards, and hopefully see some cool stuff.
Surprisingly beautiful with some of the most relaxing music and some of the most beautiful sights. Not an actual game but, who cares? This is awesome!

Proteus is a pixelated, first-person adventure game where you explore the island of Proteus and interact with its inhabitants. The artwork, sounds, and music are very good for the most part, and the first half of the game makes you curious and intrigued as to what different sights there are to see on the island and how to interact with different things that you find (as the game offers no instructions or tutorial, but instead lets you find out how to play and explore Proteus on your own.)  The second half of the game, however, is very dull and boring, and these negative aspects worsen until the game finishes. Also, after 1 or 2 playthroughs, you've pretty much seen everything, as Protues is a very short title that should take less than an hour to complete, and there's no incentive to play again. In fact, the painfully dull second half of the game may DETER players from exploring Proteus again.  In short, the first half of Proteus is quite well done, but considering the boring second half and lack of replay value, the positive qualities of this game are not enough to recommend a purchase.

If you're the sort of person who finds bits of geography very significant, you'll probably love this game. I don't, and I was left completely indifferent.  If you are considering buying this for Mac OS, don't. It barely works, and the inexplicably terrible performance completely ruins any mood.

This game is gorgeous, only being based around just exploration. No hunger bars or health bars, just being calm. I personally chill wif a cup of tea and play it ^-^ it is beautiful and it's just decorated with amazing music, best playedd with headphones. I will always love this game, it shall never be boring, plus cheaper than it should be.

If you want art out of your games, this is about as artgame as it's going to get. This is peak artgame. This is so artgame there were actual debates over if it deserved to be called a game. Which is a dumb debate, but the fact that said debate had to happen is indicative of exactly how artgame this is. I loved it, but I have a hyperflexible spine that allows me to place my head inside of my ♥♥♥.
Its like if you had a really great dream inside an atari style game.
Wonderfully relaxing.

If you're bored quickly, don't buy this game. But if you wanna discover a new genre that, unlike other video games, eases your mind instead of occupies it. Play this right before you go to sleep and you'll easily fall asleep: the game has a meditative effect on you that I personally love.
Art. Nothing else needs to be said.

Proteus is, in my opinion, the most beautiful game I have ever played. It's a quiet game about exploring and experiencing an unknown world. In this world, you are rewarded for your curiosity--but not in the 'bonus points' and 'level up' sort of reward. Instead, your reward for what you discover is the very witnessing of what you've uncovered. The world is fully immersive if you let it be--immaculately gorgeous and warmly sonorous. Proteus is a game that asks for your wonder. If you give it, you will experience something both comfortably familiar and excitingly new.

I had just finished a stressful match of League of Legends and I decided that I needed to take a breather, so I loaded up Steam and remembered I had just bought this game as apart of a Humble Bundle. Figuring that it could be good, I installed it, put on my headphones, and dove in. Waking up waist deep in the pixelated ocean, I was immersed in a simple yet utterly beautiful world. I watched day turn to night and night turn to day. There were no goals, nor any rules of what I had to do. I walked around an island, listening to the world. I climbed a mountain and heard the sea wind blowing. I walked into the rain and heard a gentle drizzle land on the nearby trees. As I played-- no, not played. As I experienced Proteus, I felt my muscles relieve themselves, and even now do I feel utterly calm. I can't explain this game, because it's not a game. Walking through Proteus was a reminder that the world is beautiful, and all we have to do is take time to see it.
While you do not do much, this game is great for just relieving stress. Exploring the islands and watching time go by is really relaxing.
Brilliant.

This isn't a game you can win, but when you play it you'll walk away as a winner. Essentially you go through the island's seasons and experience the hell out of it. The things you can see and the objects near you affect the sound scape. The graphics aren't much but when you combine the experience of sound and motion the game becomes something more.
Surprisingly beautiful with some of the most relaxing music and some of the most beautiful sights. Not an actual game but, who cares? This is awesome!
A very relaxing experience!
This is the longest and most expensive music video you will ever watch. I suggest copious amounts of acid before you play.
It is simply beatiful
the sequel to dayZ, the worlds previous best walking simulator

Although I don't entirely agree with the price, it is a relaxing game to listen to, sometimes I hop on the game just to hear a certain song in one of the seasons but I dont know if it should be called a game more that a mere visual novelty. I guess you just have to be into this sort of thing. I would only recommened it to individuals that are fans of the music genre thats in the game.

This is probably (hopefully) the only serious Steam review I'll write while not in a fit of rage. Proteus is something. I know I haven't played it much, but if you see it as an immersive experience rather than a game with a goal, it'll be a lot better. If you need something to de-stress or if you suffer any form of anxiety, I would say drop the $10 and get this.  It's a good way to just take a step out of the world and relax.

I'm not sure what I expected with this game because it really is very different. I ended up greatly enjoying it though! It definitely isn't for everyone. If you are the kind of person who enjoys stopping to smell the flowers instead of getting caught up in the rat race, if you enjoy admiring beauty in the smallest of things and taking a moment out of your day to drink it all in, then I would say this game is for you. This is a stop-and-smell-the-roses game, I can't think of any better way to describe it. It brings a sense of serenity and calm when playing and I love all the strange animals and plants, and the unique sounds each one makes. Chasing them down to listen to them is half the fun!
I don't get it... Boring and pointless...?

This shouldn't be allowed to be called a game. Its a interactive screen saver where the only interaction is to walk forward. You need to be high to enjoy this game since its the same thing after the first 10 mins. There is nothing but the same old trees and clouds, just different color.   If they didn't call this a game, it wouldn't be so bad but judging it as a game, its worthless. 0/10.

If you look at it for what it is, an adventure game, it is an amazing PROGRAM. I use that term because it is not a game. The only connection to game is the WASD and joystick controlles. Wonder around, enjoy the simplisity. While going though this, simply relax.

The first two or three times I played this I quit after a few minutes, thinking I must be missing something. Finally I stuck with it and really embraced its open exploration. It was worth it.  If you've ever played Minecraft and just enjoyed wandering to see what lies over the next hill, you can enjoy this game.

It is kind of like a game without what makes a game a game. Take an octopus for example, beautiful aquatic creature with 8 arms, now take that octopus, rip off its arms and place it in a desert, that is what this game is, an armless octopus in the desert. It feels like I'm playing an incomplete game, like a game in very early alpha.  I recommend a game with a beautiful world that when you get tired of exploring you can go and do other things.

My young kids (ages 3 & 5) absolutely love this game. It's very artistic in a semi-abstract style which lets them exercise their imaginations, and I don't have to worry about them getting mauled by 'bad guys' while they explore the world. The music accompanying the world is beautiful as well. The game to me seems to be geared toward self-paced exploration and allows you to interpret it for yourself.  I enjoy wandering the world myself, and my kids enjoy watching me.

A beautiful game that doesn't offer a single objective. You just wander as you progress through the days and the seasons; hearing the interesting sounds and observing the amazing sights around you. This game is very pretty, but not for everyone.  I recommend buying it on sale. The replay value is rather low despite the randomly generated islands.
Play this groovy game to get lost in a soothing world and subtle story.

Pretty island simulator. Not much going on in there though. Just some rabbits hopping, birds chirping, wormhole ripping the fabric of time, sky becoming blood red during the night when close to the totem poles.

I cant really reccomend. For example, upon startup, its very glitchy, there are holes in the game, allowing you too see through trees and hills. I also kind of wish there was another element besides walking, maybe a jump? Something to interact with?
It was a beautiful Zen game that made me feel relaxed and happy, and the ending had me sitting in my seat with mouth agape in total awe! I definitely recommend this game!

Perhaps the most relaxing game I have ever played. The tranquil island was an absolute pleasure to explore. I've played through exactly once - and I don't plan on playing again for quite a while. Not because I am tired of the game, but because this first experience was overwhelmingly beautiful and I'd like to recollect on it for a while first.  It's certainly not for everyone- but if you enjoy experiences such as 'Dear Esther' or 'Eidolon', I believe you'll love Proteus. It's hard to explain the sense of wonder I had as I discovered how the island worked- akin to stumbling upon the touchpad in the field in 'The Vanishing of Ethan Carter'
Strangely satisfying, but don't expect any sort of actual gameplay. You just kinda walk around. It's trippy, but also super chill.

Deep within the shadow of a memory of a dream you once had, you recall an island, familiar to you and yet foreign. Awakening offshore you stumble onto the beach, the light of a Spring sun above you. All about you is music of your making, a strange beautiful melody crafted merely by your presence here. The notes drift through the air, tumble through the leaves of the trees and blow wistfully through the grass with the wind.  As night falls, you walk among fireflies, following a trail of standing stones that hum and mumble as you touch them. With the moon high above, you find a ring of the mumbling stones, and inside the warm light of the fireflies dances in a circle with your tune... the world begins to change...  10/10 would do shrooms again. Also Proteus is a great game.
legit worst game I've ever played in my life.

This game is extraordinary. It is a trip. Despite what some have said, IT IS A GAME and it can be beaten. There are multiple ways to beat the game. Each time is a unique experience. You really gotta go into it with an open mind and crack this one open. If you're down for cool visuals and sounds, a relaxing experience where dying and killing isn't part of the experience, and easter eggs along the way, this game is for you. I wish there were more games out there like this!
This.. I ... just... what... I... glorious. Nothing has made me feel this sense of wonder since I was a kid.
It is a beautiful game, but I would like to hear more than a few beeps, boops, and twinkles.
Probably the most chill game I've ever played. Highly recommended for anyone going through a stressful time.
I experienced.

More of an interactive experience than a game as their does not seem to be a defined goal...however, it is an experience you should have. Put 30 minutes to an hour aside, put your headphones on, omit all distractions, and enjoy Proteus.
This game is truely beautiful

Proteus is basically an island you can generate with your computer. There's a full range of plants and animals, a handful of landmarks, and a couple of secrets and surprises. Although there isn't much to do in Proteus, the procedurally generated landscape, fudgy graphics, and kaleidoscopic sound occasionally come together into something worth bearing witness to. If nothing else, Proteus can be enjoyed passively and functions well as a palette cleanser.  There also exists a free mod called Purgateus, which uses alternate graphics and sound to create a darker setting.

Proteus was one of the first games that really challenged the common perception of what means to BE a game, and I think that the game holds up incredibly well as an excercise in creating your own enjoyment out of a beautiful open environment.
I love this game. It's more of a work of art and it's very peaceful. Fantastic if you need to relax and have a good time

'Do you recommend this game?' is actually quite a hard question with regard to Proteus. I would not recommend Proteus to most people. But I would recommend my experience of Proteus. If I could be sure that someone else would feel the same wonder at wandering around a colourful, pixelated island, chasing critters and getting caught up in some kind of sprite island-changing dance party, then I would recommend Proteus to them. But I can't really be sure of that.  I also can't really be sure of how they'll feel about the cost. I have only spent a little over half-an-hour with Proteus myself and haven't felt the urge to go back. (Not that I won't.) But for some, understandably, that's not enough for their money. (I got it in a bundle.)  This is one of those situations where an inbetween would be great. But as we don't have one, I'm not sure I can recommend Proteus to others. :/
